title: Part A
stimulusHtml:
2 points maximum

Evidence to support autosomal inheritance (1 point)

· Inherited equally by males and females

· Both males and females have equal chance of transmitting the trait

Evidence to support dominant inheritance (1 point)

· Phenotype is most likely observed in each generation.

· If the trait is not observed in one generation it will not be observed in subsequent generations.

· There are no unaffected carriers of the allele.

· Each affected individual must have one or more affected parent.
descriptions:
Student response earns none of the following points.

Evidence to support autosomal inheritance (1 point)

· Inherited equally by males and females

· Both males and females have equal chance of transmitting the trait

Evidence to support dominant inheritance (1 point)

· Phenotype is most likely observed in each generation.

· If the trait is not observed in one generation it will not be observed in subsequent generations.

· There are no unaffected carriers of the allele.

· Each affected individual must have one or more affected parent.

Student response earns one of the following points.

· Inherited equally by males and females

· Both males and females have equal chance of transmitting the trait

Evidence to support dominant inheritance (1 point)

· Phenotype is most likely observed in each generation.

· If the trait is not observed in one generation it will not be observed in subsequent generations.

· There are no unaffected carriers of the allele.

· Each affected individual must have one or more affected parent.

Student response earns two of the following points.

Evidence to support autosomal inheritance (1 point)

· Inherited equally by males and females

· Both males and females have equal chance of transmitting the trait

Evidence to support dominant inheritance (1 point)

· Phenotype is most likely observed in each generation.

· If the trait is not observed in one generation it will not be observed in subsequent generations.

· There are no unaffected carriers of the allele.

· Each affected individual must have one or more affected parent.

title: Part B
stimulusHtml:
4 points maximum
Results of Calculation (2 points)
NOTE: Points are earned in one bullet point only

1695 (1 point)

· Response demonstrates understanding of triplet code in production of polypeptide.

(565 amino acids × 3 nucleotides = 1695)

1698 (2 points)

· Response demonstrates understanding of triplet code in production of polypeptide.

· Response demonstrates understanding of the role of the stop codon in terminating translation.

(1695 + 3 = 1698)

1701 (2 points)

· Response demonstrates understanding of triplet code in production of polypeptide.

· Response demonstrates understanding of the role of the start and stop codons in production of polypeptides from which the initial methionione is excised.

(1695 + 3 + 3 = 1701)

Reasoning (2 points)

· RNA is modified or processed.

· Introns are removed from mRNA but remain in the gene structure.

· 5' cap adds a nucleotide that is not encoded by the gene.

· PolyA tail adds nucleotides to the 3' end of the mRNA that are not encoded by the gene.

· The gene has regulatory sequences (promoters/enhancers) that are not transcribed.

· Alternative splicing mixes different exons

title: Part C
stimulusHtml:
1 point maximum

· A ➔ G OR AUG ➔ GUG (from the codon table)

· T ➔ C

· A/T ➔ G/C
descriptions:
Student response earns none of the following points.

· A ➔ G OR AUG ➔ GUG (from the codon table)

· T ➔ C

· A/T ➔ G/C

Student response earns one of the following points.

· A ➔ G OR AUG ➔ GUG (from the codon table)

· T ➔ C

· A/T ➔ G/C

title: Part D
stimulusHtml:
3 points maximum

· Mutation causes a structural change in polypeptide.

· Change in sequence activates signaling (a gain of function).

· Change in sequence decreases signaling pathway (a loss of function).

· An altered protein could change other components of the signaling pathway (downstream effect).

o Buildup or loss of ATP

o Increase or decrease of phosphorylated proteins

o An effect on the overall cascade

o Buildup or decrease of signal molecule

o Interferes with the growth factor/affects growth
descriptions:
